_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary

EPA Facility # 100000233124

3815 Marion St.

Albany, OR 97308



The Following subsections outline the Executive Summary requirements for EPA's 40 CFR Part 68.155



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTIONS AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

SnoTemp located at 3815 Marion St. Albany, Oregon abides by the emergency response procedures detailed in the Emergency Response Plan.  The plan is designed to meet the following objectives:

To save lives

To protect the environment

To minimize property damage



SnoTemp's Emergency Response Team are the designated emergency coordinators.  The Plan provides response organization, ammonia health hazards, evacuation routes and mitigation procedures to respond to emergency situations at the facility.  The Plan is reviewed once a year or as needed to ensure compliance with PSM and RMP regulations or for facility changes.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

SnoTemp maintains thermal environments for food item storage.  The system consists of an ammonia refrigeration system which includes compressors, condensers, evaporators, vessels and piping.  Controls consist of a secure computerized system which follows user defined set points and provides alarms if any safety parameters are breached.  Ammonia the refrigerant is changed from liquid to vapor as it absorbs heat then changed back to a liquid through pressure increases and heat dissipation.  This process of changing the state of ammonia removes heat from insulated rooms and expels the heat outside the system.  Typical operating pressures range from 0 psig to 140 psig across this process.



Anyrdrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) is the refrigerant used in this system.



The total ammonia quantity of this system is above the 10,000 pound threshold quantity for reporting.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The SnoTemp facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia (IIAR) guidelines and standa

rds including the following:



IIAR Bulletin 107 - "Suggested Safety and Operating Procedures When Making Ammonia Refrigeration Tie-ins"

IIAR Bulletin 109 - "Minimum Safety Criteria for a Safe Ammonia Refrigeration System"

IIAR Bulletin R1 - A guide to Good Practices for the Operation of an Ammonia Refrigeration System"



In addition, SnoTemp has implemented a Process Safety Management program for compliance with the OSHA 1910.119 regulation.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no reportable releases of ammonia at this facility over the last five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Albany SnoTemp facility has an Emergency Response Program in place.  Team members have all had 40 hour or 24 hour HAZWOPER training with annual 8 hour refresher training.  We only respond to levels below 300 ppm.  We have much capability to respond remotely through our refrigeration control system.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

During development of PSM and RMP for this facility we found we needed improvements in training of emergency procedures.  Additional enunciators and sensors were installed and are regularly calibrated by an outside contractor.  Scheduled evacuation drills have been added to our job tracker scheduling program.
